name: uranium production, in yellowcake, in-situ leaching | uranium, in yellowcake | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/14115/documentation

This dataset is solely for the technology of in-situ leaching (ISL) of uranium, in other words, excluding the conventional open-pit and underground mining of uranium. In 2013 ISL made up 46% of the worlds uranium mine supply (World Uranium Mining Production, 2013, available at http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/Nuclear-Fuel-Cycle/Mining-of-Uranium/World-Uranium-Mining-Production/), however in this dataset, the production volume in 2011 is referred, in order to keep the consistency of reference year between this dataset and the dataset for uranium, in yellowcake production by conventional technologies.;;ISL produces yellowcake without milling and therefore replaces the;functions of mining and milling. The function unit in this dataset is 1 kg of yellowcake as natural uranium.;; For the inventory, diesel consumption in mining is estimated based on WNA 2009-27, Heathgate 2006, p/45 and Mudd & Diesendorf 2007. Both Heathgate 2006 and Mudd & Diesendorf 2007 refer to data in ISL site in Beverley Australia. Acid consumption is estimated from WNA 2009-27. Water consumption is estimated from Mudd & Diesendorf 2007. Emissions of radon-222 is estimated from the report IAEA 2005. Steel consumption for injection and recovery wells in remediation is estimated based on an assumed site, with  recovery rate of uranium assumed based on Red Book 203, p.265. No re-use or recycling of steel is considered in this dataset. The energy intensity in remediation is assumed to be identical to uranium mining, as the processes are similar: both include pumping and separation. Land transformation and occupation is estimated based an assumed site. Groundwater emissions are calculated using the Ecoinvent residual landfill model, in Doka 2008.;;References:;;WNA 2009-27: World Nuclear Association (2009) In Situ Leach Mining (ISL) of Uranium. WNA Information Paper, June 2009. http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf27.html (11 June 2010);;Heathgate 2006: Heathgate Resources (2006) Annual Environment Report 2005 , Heathgate Resources Pty Ltd, Adelaide, 31 March 2006. http://www.heathgateresources.com.au/public/download.jsp?id=777 (16 April 2010);;Mudd & Diesendorf 2007: Mudd G. M., Diesendorf M. (2007) Sustainability Aspects of Uranium Mining : Towards Accurate Accounting ? 2nd International Conference on Sustainability Engineering and Science, Auckland, New Zealand, February 2007. http://civil.eng.monash.edu.au/about/staff/muddpersonal/2007-SustEngSci-Sust-v-Uranium-Mining.pdf (25 June 2007);;IAEA 2005: IAEA (2005) Guidebook on environmental impact assessment for in situ leach mining projects. IAEATECDOC-1428, International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, May 2005. http://wwwpub.iaea.org/MTCD/publications/PDF/te_1428_web.pdf (17. April 2010);;Red Book 2003: Uranium 2003: Resources, Production and Demand. NEA report Nr. 5291, OECD Nuclear Energy Agency and International Atomic Energy Agency IAEA, Paris 2004.;;Doka 2008: Doka G. (2008) Non-radiological emissions from uranium tailings: A generic, global model for Life Cycle;Inventory data. Doka Life Cycle Assessments, Zurich, November 2008.;Note that the dry mass of this dataset is not balanced, which is mostly caused by the relatively large long-term and short-term emissions from sulphate and nitrate, but this is the groundwater emissions from residual landfill directly taken from the Tab. 2.1 in the Doka 2011 reference. The dry mass won't be balanced in this technology, as the pregnant solution has introduced a lot of other substances from underground, which are not considered in the inputs. ;;Please note that this dataset is the first tentative dataset for the mining of uranium by in-situ leaching, with limited data and information. Future improvements on data quality is necessary.

The activity starts from uranium under the ground

The activity includes: input of diesel that needs to be fed into the diesel generators; acid consumption for in-situ dissolvation of uranium; water consumption; radon emissions; the requirement for steel for contructing the injection and recovery wells; diesel consumption required during drilling of the wells; remediation, which includes water and energy consumption, leachate reatment, landfill of residual material; land transformation and occupation; resource extraction and recovery.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0721:Mining of uranium and thorium ores

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Global dataset for uranium mining with in-situ leaching technology represented by data derieved from Australia and Kazakhstan.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In-situ leaching (ISL), also called in-situ recovery (ISR) or solution mining, is a mining process used to recover minerals through boreholes drilled into a deposit in situ. The process initially involves drilling of holes into the ore deposit. Leaching solution is pumped into the deposit via a borehole, where it makes contact with the ore. The solution bearing the dissolved ore content is then extracted via a second borehole and pumped to the surface being further processed. This process allows the extraction of metals from an ore body without the need for conventional mining involving drill-and-blast, open-cut or underground mining. The technology parameters for this particular dataset is dereived from data for urainium production activity with in-situ leaching process from 2005 to 2009 in Australia and Kazakhstan.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Yes, there are extrapolation based on other references, The energy demand in mining is derived from WNA 2009-27, Heathgate 2006 and Mudd & Diesendorf 2007; the acid consumption are derived from WNA 2009-27; emissions of radon is derived from IAEA 2005; resource extraction and recovery is extrapolated based on acid ISL process given in Red Book 2003; while steel consumption, energy demand in remediation landuse are estimated with assumptions in calculation; and groundwater emissions are estimated using ecoinvent residual landfill model, from Doka 2008.

References:

WNA 2009-27: World Nuclear Association (2009) In Situ Leach Mining (ISL) of Uranium. WNA Information Paper, June 2009. http://www.world-nuclear.org/info/inf27.html (11 June 2010)

Heathgate 2006: Heathgate Resources (2006) Annual Environment Report 2005 , Heathgate Resources Pty Ltd, Adelaide, 31 March 2006. http://www.heathgateresources.com.au/public/download.jsp?id=777 (16 April 2010)

Mudd & Diesendorf 2007: Mudd G. M., Diesendorf M. (2007) Sustainability Aspects of Uranium Mining : Towards Accurate Accounting ? 2nd International Conference on Sustainability Engineering and Science, Auckland, New Zealand, February 2007. http://civil.eng.monash.edu.au/about/staff/muddpersonal/2007-SustEngSci-Sust-v-Uranium-Mining.pdf (25 June 2007)

IAEA 2005: IAEA (2005) Guidebook on environmental impact assessment for in situ leach mining projects. IAEATECDOC-1428, International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, May 2005. http://wwwpub.iaea.org/MTCD/publications/PDF/te_1428_web.pdf (17. April 2010)

Red Book 2003: Uranium 2003: Resources, Production and Demand. NEA report Nr. 5291, OECD Nuclear Energy Agency and International Atomic Energy Agency IAEA, Paris 2004.

Doka 2008: Doka G. (2008) Non-radiological emissions from uranium tailings: A generic, global model for Life Cycle
Inventory data. Doka Life Cycle Assessments, Zurich, November 2008.
http://www.doka.ch/PSIuraniumtailingsDoka.pdf (19 Feb 2009)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature (inventory data is referenced from literature report Life Cycle Inventory of generic uranium in-situ leaching by Gabor Doka, Doka Life Cycle Assessment, ZÃ¼rich, 2011) unless otherwise specified in the particular input comment field.

flow.name: Chromium VI
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/ground water

exchanges.description: The diesel consumption here includes diesel consumption in two processes: uranium mining and remedation. Diesel consumption in uranium mining is referenced from WNA 2009-27 (253 MJ diesel/kg U) , while the intensity of diesel consumption in remediation is assumed to be identical to uranium ming, as methods they are using are similar: pumping and separation. However, since the proces of remediation is longer (5 years) than that of mining process (2.5 years), the energy requirement is scaled up by 5 years Ã· 2 years = 2.5 times, which equals to 253*2.5=633.3 MJ diesel/kg U. The total diesel consumption therefore becomes 253+633.3=886.3 MJ diesel/kg of U.

exchanges.description:
No data was found for the specific infrastructure of an ISL field. Therefore assumed site was used to estimate landuse, with 20m-edge, hexagonal wellfield pattern geometry with central recovery well, wells running 120m deep and 10 kg steel per metre of piping, 15 m ore aquifer height with 0.168% U3O8 ore grade and 75% overall recovery rate (Red Book 2003), resulting in 32 kg U recovered per m2 surface area.

This gives a landuse estimate of 1 m^2/32 kg=0.0312 m^2/kg U

flow.name: Transformation, to unspecified
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description: No data was found for the specific infrastructure of an ISL field. Therefore, an estimate of the probably most important part - the injection and recovery pipes was made based on a assumed site, with 20m-edge, hexagonal wellfield pattern geometry with central recovery well, wells running 120m deep and 10 kg steel per metre of piping, 15 m ore aquifer height with 0.168% U3O8 ore grade and 75% overall recovery rate (Red Book 2003, p.265). This results in 32 kg U recovered per m2 surface area and 0.108 kg steel pre kg uranium recovered.

exchanges.description: Recovery rate of uranium of about 75% is assumed, based on Red Book 2003. Non-recovered uranium (0.33 kg) is assumed to remain underground, but is assumed to be worthless uranium leftover in an exploited deposit. There for it is inventoried as resource extraction for the impact assessment.

Estimated based on IAEA 2005: 43100 kBq Rn-222/kg U, which is given as upper estimate of 100 GBq per day, converted with annual production of 1000 t
yellowcake in same production = 847 t U. This is figure is reduced by 50% to be 21550 kBq Rn-222/kg U,

exchanges.description:
Literature value. 

Note that there might seem to be a mass balance gap, but the reason behind is that the underground is not inventoried as an input material (only uranium resource itself is).  Sulfate emitted to water here is not from the operational inputs of sulphuric acid, but from the 5-year remediation phase of the mine site (and subsequent landfilling of isolated pollutants). The long-term emissions to water here may look a bit high, but given 25'000 liters of flushing water used per kg of produced uranium, a total 155 kg of sulfate in 25'000 kg water is about the concentration of mineral water. The ISL reactions will chemically change the underground. The mine's remediation phase will bring pollutants to the surface where they are separated and landfilled, probably at a different location, where a certain part will be emitted over time.
